# Anaemia

## Case Protocol 28 – **Pernicious Anaemia**

**Case:** A *54-year-old woman was referred to a specialist physician by her local doctor. She had a five-month history of malaise, lethargy, glossitis, paraesthesia and numbness of the extremities, easy bruising and over the past two weeks had noticed increasing breathlessness on mild exertion.*

[](data:image/png;base64,)

*Physical examination revealed a pale, grey-haired, blue-eyed woman with a sallow complexion. Her tongue was beefy-red and tender. There was reduced pain and touch sensation in a “glove and stoking” distribution, together with reduced vibration sense and proprioception in the lower limbs. There were bilateral upgoing plantar responses.*

- Provisional and differential to this case
    - Provisional: pernicious anaemia with resultant B12 deficiency
        - Glossitis
        - Megaloblastic anaemia → lethargy, malaise
        - LMN lesions → peripheral neuropathy → paraesthesia, numbness, reduced pain and touch sensation
        - UMN lesions → SCD
        - Specific case: peripheral neuropathy with upgoing plantar response
    - DDx
        - Folate deficiency → does not explain CNS manifestations
        - Other causes of anaemia → iron deficiency, chronic disease, haemolysis
        - Vasculitides (e.g. SLE, medium vessel, small vessel) → pancytopaenia, neuropathy
        - Malignancy
- Approach to history and examination
    - History
        - HOPC
            - Constitutional symptoms (malignanct, systemic illness)
            - Infective symptoms (causes of dyspnoea)
            - Symptoms of systemic vasculitides (arthralgia, rash)
            - Symptoms of malabsorption (abdominal pain, changes in stools, diarrhoea, haematochezia)
        - PMHx
            - Autoimmune disorders
            - Previous medical conditions
        - Meds, allergies
        - FHx
            - History of autoimmune conditions, malignancy
        - SHx
            - Diet - vegetarian or vegan
            - Alcohol intake (?malnutrition with AUD)
            - Chance of pregnancy - folate?
    - Examination
        - General inspection - vital signs
        - Haematological examination
            - Pallor
            - Purpura, ecchymoses
            - Angular stomatitis, atrophic glossitis
            - Organomegaly (especially hepatosplenomegaly)
            - Bone tenderness
            - Lymphadenopathy
        - Neurological examination
            - Focus on signs of peripheral neuropathy and reflexes
- Approach to causes of anaemia
    - Microcytic
        - Defective haem synthesis
            - Iron deficiency
                - Caused by decreased intake (diet), decreased absorption (coeliac, surgery, pernicious anaemia) or increased loss (bleeding)
                - Low ferritin, high transferrin
            - Anaemia of chronic disease (severe)
            - Sideroblastic anaemia
                - Caused by defective protoporphyrin ring synthesis → impaired haem production → microcytic anaemia
                    - Congenital (ALA synthase gene mutation) or acquired (alcohol, lead poisoning)
                - Classic findings
                    - Peripheral smear: RBCs with basophilic stippling
                    - Bone marrow: ringed sideroblasts with Prussian-blue stained mitochondria
                    - Iron studies: high serum iron, high ferritin
        - Defective globin synthesis
            - Thalassaemias, HbC disease
        - Causes: FIST
            - Fe deficiency
            - Inherited (sideroblastic)
            - Severe anaemia of chronic disease
            - Thalassaemias
    - Normocytic
        - Haemolytic (reticulocute index > 2%)
            - Intrinsic
                - Membrane defects
                    - Hereditary spherocytosis
                - Enzyme deficiencies
                    - G6PD deficiency
                    - Pyruvate kinase deficiency
                - Haemoglobinopathies
                    - Sickle cell anaemia
            - Extrinsic
                - Autoimmune
                - Microangiopathic
                - Macroangiopathic
                - Infectious
        - Non-haemolytic
            - Anaemia of chronic disease
            - Haemorrhage
            - Bone marrow suppression
    - Macrocytic
        - Megaloblastic (megaloblasts are immature large red cells)
            - Defective DNA synthesis
                - Folate or B12 deficiency
                    - Will also see hypersegmented neutrophils and platelet abnormalities
            - Defective DNA repair
                - Fanconi anaemia
        - Non-megaloblastic
            - Myelodysplastic syndrome
            - Alcoholism
            - Liver disease
- Investigative approach to anaemia
    - Primary investigations
        - FBC
        - Peripheral blood film
        - Iron studies
            - Identify Fe deficiency (ferritin most sensitive)
        - Bilirubin, serum LDH, serum haptoglobin → signs of haemolysis
        - Folate and B12 level
            - In pernicious anaemia, expect normal folate and low B12
    - Investigations specific for pernicious anaemia
        - Bloods
            - Anti-parietal cell antibody
            - Anti-intrinsic factor antibody
        - Procedural
            - Gastroscopy → atrophic gastritis and achlorhydria
            - Nerve conduction studies
            - Bone marrow aspirate and trephine → rule out malignancy if suspecting
    - Ancillary investigations
        - UEC, LFT
        - Coagulation studies
        - CRP
- Pernicious anaemia
    - An autoimmune reaction with antibodies against gastric parietal cell and/or intrinsic factor
        - Results in autoimmune destruction of parietal cells and deficiency of intrinsic factor
        - Presentation
            - Chronic atrophic gastritis and achlorhydria
                - Increased risk of gastric cancer
            - Malabsorption of B12
                - Intrinsic factor is essential for B12 absorption in the terminal ileum
                    - Megaloblastic anaemia
                    - Glossitis
                    - Neurological effects
                        - Subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord
                        - Peripheral neuropathy
                        - Dementia
    - Risk factors: older age, family history or genetic predisposition, other autoimmune conditions, ethnicity (Northern European), previous bariatric surgery/gastrectomy
    - Pathophysiology
        - Normal absorption of B12
            - B12 is bound to transcobalamin I (salivary gland secretion) in the mouth
                - Degraded in the acidic stomach and binds to intrinsic factor
                - Absorbed at the terminal ileum and travels in the circulation to transcobalamin II
            - Impaired absorption due to both achlorhydria and intrinsic factor deficiency
        - Normal function of B12
            - B12 is a cofactor for methionine synthase (conversion of essential AA methionine from homocysteine)
                - Methionine is essential to form tetrahydrofolate (active form of folate) produced by dihydrofolate reductase
                - Folate is important for amino acid metabolism and DNA synthesis
            - Deficiency of B12 or folate results in decreased synthesis of cells with rapid turnover
            - Note:
                - Large B12 reserve (3-6 years) and regular dietary intake usually exceeds demand (50-100x)
                    - Uncommon to have true B12 deficiency
                - Folate stores last 3-6 months and is more common (developed countries often fortify foods with folate to minimise risks)
    - Complications
        - Irreversible gastric atrophy and achlorhydria
            - Increased risk of gastric cancer (2-3x)
            - Secondary iron deficiency (acidic pH needed to convert iron into its absorbable form)
        - Anaemia
            - Fatigue, decreased exercise intolerance
        - Neurological deficits
- Neurological abnormalities in B12 or folate deficiency
    - Neurological deficits due to demyelination of spinal and peripheral nerves (subacute combined degeneration) [affects SCD]
        - Spinocerebellar tract
            - Gait ataxia
        - lateral Corticospinal tract
            - Spastic paresis (UMN)
        - Dorsal column-medial lemniscus
            - Paraesthesia, numbness, impaired proprioception and vibration sense
            - Impaired two-point position discrimination
    - Other
        - Neuropsychiatric disease (depression, dementia)
        - Autonomic dysfunction
    - Pathophysiology
        - B12 has a role in fatty acid metabolism (conversion of methyl-malonyl CoA → succinyl CoA)
            - Loss of B12 and build-up of **methylmalonic acid** → impaired myelination
                - Can detect MMA levels clinically
            - Impaired conversion of homocysteine to methionine → impaired phospholipid synthesis for neuronal function + toxic homocysteine accumulation
- Autoimmune polyglandular syndrome (thyrogastric cluster)
    - Cluster of disorders
        - Pernicious anaemia
        - Thyroid diseases
            - Hashimoto’s thyroidiitis
            - Graves’ disease
        - Adrenal insufficiency (Addison’s)
        - Type 1 DM
    - Associated with vitiligo, myasthenia gravis
        - Vitiligo is an autoimmune dermatological condition resulting in depigmentation (loss of melanocytes)
- Management of pernicious anaemia
    - Lifelong treatment of vitamin B12 replacement
        - IM or subcutaneous (initially weekly, then monthly)
            - Bypasses the non-functional GIT absorption pathway
        - High dose oral (in some patients with intact intestinal absorption)
